note.body:
I resort mostly to `./localsearch-3 --no-daemon` to measure indexer runs, run under the profiler of choice. This however does not observe metadata extraction (with `--no-daemon` the indexer exits without invoking the extractor), it would be nice to have a `--no-extract` option so we can combine to measure either the indexer standalone, or full end-to-end w/ metadata extraction.

Another thing that would be nice to have is sysprof marks in our code, so that it becomes easier to identify bottlenecks/etc. I reckon sysprof is amazing, it sadly has not been my friend given my development environment (silverblue with hacks to run things from a toolbox) and everything is missing symbols, other tools (heaptrack, perf, massif) have allowed me to get by.

+1 to documenting these tips, and improving our support to make profiling easy. Ideally our profiling methods should converge towards GNOME-friendly stuff.

Changes look great!

Imagine a scenario where someone else wants to measure performance of the indexer -- either trying to improve it further, or checking for regressions after code changes.

Can we make this information easier to find in the repo? 

The simplest way to do this would be  -- update HACKING.md with a section on 'Performance testing', which links to your recent MRs. We could also add some links to recommended profiling tools.

A harder way to do this would be -- write some 'stress tests' which could be run manually to actually recreate these pathological indexing scenarios, and maybe even generate memory profiles and so on. 


I'd like it if we could collect the performance testcases somewhere in the repo. At the moment, the individual writeups on the MRs are great, but will be hard to find in a couple of years.

Not sure what my preferred format for this would be. Effectively

target_title: indexer: Avoid memory payload in handling folder updates

note.body:
And this is the last known scenario for possible unbound memory growth in the indexer process, dependent on the filesystem layout. To replicate this scenario in the ugliest, I resorted to the following update to alter modification time for every file between runs:

```
tinysparql query -d ~/.cache/tracker3/files -u "

WITH tracker:FileSystem
DELETE { ?u nfo:fileLastModified ?d }
INSERT { ?u nfo:fileLastModified '1900-01-01T01:01:01Z' }
WHERE { ?u nfo:fileLastModified ?d }
"
```

This is functionally the same as `find ~ -exec touch -m {} \;` and letting the indexer handle "updates" for all indexed files/folders on next restart.

Some heaptrack screenshots to illustrate `localsearch-3 -n`, before:

![Screenshot_From_2024-12-24_18-11-42](/uploads/b202a65dd360e8ab1aa0017f14f0a8c2/Screenshot_From_2024-12-24_18-11-42.png)

And after:

![Screenshot_From_2024-12-24_18-11-27](/uploads/e97c28be987cd10ddc4949ee515f1ccb/Screenshot_From_2024-12-24_18-11-27.png)

(note that the lower orange/yellow parts switched roles between screenshots)

The handling of this worst case scenario is also a bit faster locally as measured with `time`, ~3m05s vs. ~3m30s.

Cleanup Tracker*Config objects

note.body:
Fair points, and I don't feel too strongly about doing a 4.0 release to change this stuff.

> Everyone else should learn themselves that settings are not an API entrypoint.

If we want people to learn things, the first step is to tell them :-) At https://gnome.pages.gitlab.gnome.org/localsearch/index.html I don't see any documentation of what settings are public and which are private.

I agree most should be private, but there are some which historically we have talked about in public, including: `index-recursive-directories`, `ignored-files`, and maybe even `index-removable-devices`. 

A good first step here would be to improve the docs so they tell people how to change settings. Part of this can be linking to GNOME docs (https://help.gnome.org/users/gnome-help/stable/files.html.en); but we also have non-GNOME users, who might use `localsearch3 index` to configure things. And we can end this section by saying "All settings not listed here are considered private and may be removed or changed in future releases"

target_title: Cleanup Tracker*Config objects

note.body:
> The initial-sleep and throttle features should move to systemd and cgroups config respectively, IMO.

Agreed.

> The other stuff is a bit more tricky. I don't really like to remove this stuff without doing a new major release.

IMO the tricky part for most is finding sane defaults that do not lead to complains.

With my gsettings-desktop-schemas and gnome-settings-daemon hats, I have quite some background in maintaining setting schemas that are public API, schemas that are not public API but were used as such, and dealing with the fallout resulting at places that forget to check the existence/availability of this not-quite-api settings beforehand.

And honestly I don't want any of that for LocalSearch. In my book the only consumers of LocalSearch settings are 1) its own CLI, and 2) Settings, which should double check everything with GSettingsSchema and know to bail out. Everyone else should learn themselves that settings are not an API entrypoint.

IMO the LocalSearch major number should be just directed by its D-Bus API, as that is what applications consume. But if you feel too strongly about this, I surely will feel less strongly about bumping LocalSearch to 4.x, provided that it can be tackled within a single cycle.

> We could get in the habit of asking bug reports to do `gsettings list-recursively org.freedesktop.Tracker3.Miner.Files` to check if they sabotaged something

Self-inflicted pain is indeed a possibility. My concern with keeping these settings "forever" in 3.x is that many of them can be misused to "silence" the indexer:

- Setting a huge free disk space requirement
- Setting crawling interval to MAXINT days
- Setting initial sleep to months worth of seconds

Or reduce the indexer functionality/effectiveness:

- All of the above with less insane numbers
- Setting throttle to 0 to make the indexer ultra-slow
- Disabling monitors just means more stuff to reindex the next time
- Same with index-on-battery, when our operation bursts from monitor events shouldn't be anywhere near being a battery drain.
- Disabling unaccent missing results through fts:match

I tend to think we should be careful at exposing settings that may end up working against us, and ideally stick more to settings that tell the indexer what to do instead of how to do.

target_title: tracker-miners 3.7.4 exiting with error code

note.body:
I guess you refer to this line:

```
Dec 14 08:21:39 tracker-miner-f[4344]: Extractor subprocess died unexpectedly: Child process exited with code 1
```

But I see nothing wrong per se in that behavior. This is just a symptom that the `file:///home/_homedir/Documents/software/lenovo/t450s_hmm_en_sp40g54937.pdf` file is taking the metadata extractor based on libpoppler far too long to extract metadata.

Unfortunately, Poppler is a library likely to trigger our imposed deadlines, e.g. on documents that are too long and/or too heavy to render (e.g. containing many large images). The extractor process (tracker-extract-3) will simply detect metadata extraction stalled for 5 seconds, and exit with an error in order to avoid situations like infinite loops.

And that's the "extractor subprocess" that message refers about, note this message is not a warning or critical log, just an informational message. The main indexer process will just log that and immediately restart the metadata extractor process, which your later log lines show happening.

The other reporter in that bodhi update refers to crashes, I am more interested in a backtrace for that.

I'll close this issue meanwhile...

target_title: tracker-miners 3.7.4 exiting with error code
Cleanup Tracker*Config objects

note.body:
There is the lingering question about what to do with the overly exposure happening through settings. Personally, I don't like having so many tweaks for the indexer internal workings, this includes:

- The various FTS settings
- crawling-interval
- enable-monitors
- index-on-battery
- index-on-battery-first-time
- low-disk-space-limit
- initial-sleep
- throttle

IMO we should stick to good defaults/behavior, and drop all or a large portion of these settings.

But that's perhaps better done as a separate step.

note.body: It does have the luxury of convenience since we are a small team. But I agree using GStreamer the way we do feels like going off road.

target_title: tracker-miner-fs: Setup GStreamer around tracker-extract-3 restarts

note.body:
> There is OTOH a fair amount of "luggage" for a plain GstDiscoverer user.

There's also a lot you can get rid of, but personally I also wouldn't use GStreamer just for metadata extraction. Especially not if all you care about is a fixed number of formats.

target_title: tracker-miner-fs: Setup GStreamer around tracker-extract-3 restarts

note.body:
> I think considering all that, the best you can do is to use a separate registry file (there's an environment variable for that) and before each sandbox start you somehow run `gst-inspect-1.0` in the same environment as the sandbox (you'll want it to find exactly the same libraries and plugins and other dependencies, like device nodes for hardware codecs).

Agree on the general approach, I'll have a look at solving it like that.

> And then pray that you do that not in the middle of an update because otherwise things will probably fail badly :)

Much better than the situation where anything can fail anytime after an update :p.

> How do you select which plugins are to be made available in the sandbox btw? Maybe a better approach would be to statically link GStreamer and exactly those plugins into the sandbox process, or build a minimal GStreamer _you_ have control over for the sandbox?

The indexer and the sandboxed process run in the host using system libraries. Being a system component we don't ship much ourselves, and a minimal GStreamer install would still be a good bunch of plugins for us, since we want to maximally extract metadata from a number of audio/video formats.

I think if necessity reached that point I would seriously consider cutting the GStreamer middle man and extracting metadata using the same media libraries you do. There is OTOH a fair amount of "luggage" for a plain GstDiscoverer user.

target_title: tracker-miner-fs: Setup GStreamer around tracker-extract-3 restarts

note.body:
I think considering all that, the best you can do is to use a separate registry file (there's an environment variable for that) and before each sandbox start you somehow run `gst-inspect-1.0` in the same environment as the sandbox (you'll want it to find exactly the same libraries and plugins and other dependencies, like device nodes for hardware codecs).

`gst-inspect-1.0` would only incrementally update the registry, so if nothing is changed it will not do anything.

----

And then pray that you do that not in the middle of an update because otherwise things will probably fail badly :)

How do you select which plugins are to be made available in the sandbox btw? Maybe a better approach would be to statically link GStreamer and exactly those plugins into the sandbox process, or build a minimal GStreamer *you* have control over for the sandbox?

target_title: tracker-miner-fs: Setup GStreamer around tracker-extract-3 restarts

note.body:
> There's `gst_update_registry()` which you can call after `gst_init()` at any time

Thanks! I somehow missed that function.

> How do you get the new versions of the plugins into your sandbox, and when? Also how do you make sure the plugins and other libraries are in sync at that point?

That's pretty much what I am trying to solve, right now, badly, and the sandboxed extractor process may try (and fail) to update the registry on startup despite `GST_UPDATE_REGISTRY=no`. Ideally, and since the sandboxed process does not persist, it should get an ensured up-to-date pre-built registry file each time it is restarted.

Even more ideally I wouldn't want the main process to keep the GST registry memory payload, since it's a significant chunk (>30%) of the memory it uses at rest. But I consider the latter my own imposition.

target_title: Improve performance of query deleting stale resources

note.body:
I've been thinking for a while having an intermediate "algebra tree" between the SPARQL parser tree and the SQL result, that would allow for a reduction/optimization step before producing the final underlying query. It then would have been feasible to turn into an engine optimization problem.

But the linter idea is also a nice one, as there are query paths that are inherently slow. SQLite has the EXPLAIN syntax to spot perf sinkholes, I wonder if we could build on top of that.

target_title: tracker-miner-fs: Setup GStreamer around tracker-extract-3 restarts

note.body:
> My real problem is that I don't know what it entails. Is there API to do that other than gst_init()? Can I do that multiple times without additional helper processes?

There's `gst_update_registry()` which you can call after `gst_init()` at any time

> How would I detect an outdated registry if e.g. someone "dnf install/remove"d a plugin?

How do you get the new versions of the plugins into your sandbox, and when?
Also how do you make sure the plugins and other libraries are in sync at that point?

target_title: tracker-miner-fs: Setup GStreamer around tracker-extract-3 restarts

note.body:
> what's the problem of also managing the registry file in addition and making sure that it stays up to date with your selected plugins?

My real problem is that I don't know what it entails. Is there API to do that other than gst_init()? Can I do that multiple times without additional helper processes? How would I detect an outdated registry if e.g. someone "dnf install/remove"d a plugin?

My concern with it is that I am not sure it provides any advantages in fixing the problem, while apparently adding more to it. I hope you agree LocalSearch is not the place to "reverse engineer" a chunk of GStreamer.

> That's effectively what a `gst-inspect-1.0` would do (and in addition it dumps the content of the registry to stdout).

Right, perhaps calling that piped to /dev/null is enough, before each extractor process spawn. Still has a hack smell, but I'll mull over it.

note.body:
> @carlosg The notification disappeared in all the gitlab noise. If you want to get feedback and nothing happened for a week or two, please write to me on Matrix. I assume this is all solved then?

Thanks @sdroege, I'll keep in mind for the next time, "glad" to see I'm not the only one partially ignoring the to-do list in gitlab :p. Sadly this is all still in shambles, I hoped to kickstart some discussion here that would take more bandwidth than matrix allows.

> Setting `GST_REGISTRY_UPDATE=no` should always avoid creating/updating the registry but you risk getting an outdated and non-functional registry.

The sandboxed extractor process does indeed do that. And it's sadly not a silver bullet, e.g. [this Fedora Retrace report](https://retrace.fedoraproject.org/faf/problems/bthash/?bth=077750e0ca10862ddc2d41b772a9d96099ab4f8c&bth=4fa529128493c76df0801193b0ed2bb4381d7f52&bth=6ad9586aa9ad3a6c1c950443d9b429c620a1df6d&bth=45d04adf7d2ec88594f126986706a27945b934f1&bth=4d24c41596673d2b789d07db4dfadb55ba8d2bca&bth=142d2ffa2410b2179797f554f898f25d8d95fa7c&bth=2f16a3b8083285fe6cd2a2f762303a43da1588bc&bth=f2cf70c2135a9e79839847ae81895de32a440fab&bth=5021dbb1f32b07ba3492f65acc77e5a0c90273b1) happens (AFAIU) due to people doing "dnf update" without a reboot, and nothing doing `gst_init()` fully prior to the sandboxed extractor process.

As you can see from that backtrace, registry file update from the sandboxed extractor process is not fully prevented. Arguably the flexiblas dependency should not crash the way it does, but `scan_and_update_registry()` happening is already a call for trouble.

> This sounds like you want to set up the sandbox so that only the plugins you care about are available inside the sandbox, and also use your own registry inside the sandbox.

With "use my own registry", you mean my own registry file? Other than that, it sounds like what we are doing.

And I am unsure how could that help, our problem is that we cannot tidily call `gst_init()` often enough outside of the sandboxed process for the registry file to be ensured up-to-date when the sandboxed extractor subprocess kicks in. We would still like to follow package updates and existing plugins.

Since the sandboxed extractor process is spawned directly from the main indexer process, so far I've tried:
- Calling gst_init() in the setup function before launching the metadata extractor. Since the process receives unclean glib state, this will randomly deadlock.
- Calling gst_init()/gst_deinit() in pairs around subprocess launch, this does not work since `gst_deinit()` works the way it works.

More convoluted options include a wrapper subprocess that calls `gst_init()` before the sandbox is set up, or a helper executable that only does `gst_init()`, but having that in the localsearch/tracker-miners repository feels completely out of place...

I wonder if there is some other option I am missing, or if GStreamer could make it somehow easier (e.g. offering one such helper executable itself), or whether we should try to trigger registry updates from e.g. g-s-d.

target_title: tracker-miner-fs: Setup GStreamer around tracker-extract-3 restarts

note.body:
@carlosg The notification disappeared in all the gitlab noise. If you want to get feedback and nothing happened for a week or two, please write to me on Matrix. I assume this is all solved then?

Setting `GST_REGISTRY_UPDATE=no` should always avoid creating/updating the registry but you risk getting an outdated and non-functional registry.

> We try to minimize the GST modules being accessed in the sandboxed extractor by setting `GST_REGISTRY_UPDATE=no` in the environment and removing non-essential `GstPlugin`s after initialization

This sounds like you want to set up the sandbox so that only the plugins you care about are available inside the sandbox, and also use your own registry inside the sandbox.

target_title: Too-restrictive Landlock rules

note.body:
Special files (that are interfaces to the kernel, not containing users' data) such as `/proc/self/ns/*` cannot be explicitly restricted but they are implicitly restricted per sandbox. All other regular files such as `/etc/ld.so.cache` are denied by default (according to the handled access rights). Landlock and more generally the kernel is not aware of the (current and relative) role of files, so there is no special rules for data files. This could be handled by libraries though.

`ld.so.cache` is a bit special because it is one of the few files used by the [dynamic linker](https://www.man7.org/linux/man-pages/man8/ld.so.8.html) and I guess the `ld.so` code may open this cache file on the fly. I agree that properly handling access control for different libraries/dependencies may be challenging, but most shared objects should already be mapped when a task sandbox itself. I'd really like to get suggestions about how we could ease that part.

~~About the audit support, I think it would help to identify the origin of the request in the logs (i.e. the EIP register and the mapped library name, if any). What do you think?~~ Well, that might not be possible because of the syscall wrappers (i.e. most calls come from the libc).

target_title: Too-restrictive Landlock rules

note.body:
Thanks for the heads up @l0kod, I'll try to get around to testing your patches in combination with LocalSearch. Landlock auditing sounds like a great addition, since it's otherwise pretty much poking in the dark (and/or reading a lot of code and strace traces) when you sandbox 3rd party libraries as it's our case.

It was my understanding that landlock did implicitly allow access to certain locations deemed too basic (e.g. `/proc/self`), it didn't occur to me that at least `/etc/ld.so.cache` would not be one such place. In any case, all three files look sensible to add to the landlock sandbox rules. I'll look to prepare a merge request for that.

This sandbox is something imposed on top of a considerable amount of unaware libraries used to implement extractor modules, and given the variety of code paths depending on the metadata available in the files it will be perhaps hard to uncover quickly all possible cases. And maybe in some of those cases it will not be really desirable to follow (e.g. allowing write access for caches, while write access is generally forbidden), I hope these cases are few.

note.body:
IMO, we should avoid logging this kind of misdetection warnings as they are not really LocalSearch misbehavior, journald logging and warnings should be something reserved to unforeseen circumstances, which this one is not. And worse, it leads people to think it is us at fault, instead of their files.

We log all these misdetections in the `localsearch status` CLI tool, we should reserve this logging to that, and we should be clearer about misdetections.

> Indeed, there used to be a 'generic image' rule which passed `image/*` MIME types to GStreamer if nothing else handled them.

We might still need to add some of that back, e.g. for webp images.

target_title: "Could not get any metadata for uri" extraction errors with various image and audio files (samples attached)

note.body:
AFAICS there's no LocalSearch bug in any of these files, per the `file` CLI command:

- H*.jpg are WEBP images
- macos_logo.png is legitimately corrupt, shows broken in eog and gimp refuses to open it as "corrupted"
- rangement...jpg is a PNG file
- sidebar*.gif are skipped as too small files (less than 64bytes)
- Sound...mp3 is a WAV file
- star_trek...png is a JPG file

We only go as far as xdg-shared-mime-info goes in figuring out the detected mimetype, and thus the extraction module used. If that is mislead in any way, the wrong library will be involved, and fail.

target_title: "Could not get any metadata for uri" extraction errors with various image and audio files (samples attached)

note.body:
Thanks for sharing. Hopefully someone can find time to investigate this. Adding 'Help Wanted' label as there are very people contributing time or funding to search in GNOME right now.

> it is mysterious to me why gstreamer would be involved in the case of image files

Indeed, there used to be a 'generic image' rule which passed `image/*` MIME types to GStreamer if nothing else handled them. We removed that in 3.x if I remember right. There is still a 'generic video' and 'generic audio' rule which feeds unhandled `audio/*` and `video/*` MIME types to GStreamer. Note that LocalSearch trusts whatever is returned by the [shared-mime-info](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/xdg/shared-mime-info/) tools and sometimes issues there can cause strange behaviour here.

note.body:
In my view, the better fix is to fix the pattern matching.

The globs are processed in LocalSearch by the tracker-indexing-tree.c module. As far as I can see, they are added in [`tracker_indexing_tree_add_filter()`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/blob/main/src/miners/fs/tracker-indexing-tree.c#L640) and then are processed in [`tracker_indexing_tree_file_matches_filter()`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/blob/main/src/miners/fs/tracker-indexing-tree.c#L709). The processing depends on the version of GLib you have installed, either using [g_pattern_spec_match](https://docs.gtk.org/glib/struct.PatternSpec.html) or `g_pattern_match`. The latter of these has some caveats, so if you have GLib < 2.70, maybe that could be the issue?

There are also some tests in [tracker-indexing-tree-test.c](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/blob/main/tests/tracker-miner-fs/tracker-indexing-tree-test.c), at a glance those don't seem to cover the "filter" functionality at all so another good deed would be to improve those tests.

Any contributions here are much appreciated!

It appears that this does in fact make the warning go away. So yes, it seems like the wildcard character `?` does not work as intended when populating the `ignored-files` array ([array definition](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/blob/main/data/org.freedesktop.Tracker.Miner.Files.gschema.xml#L129))

Question is: What should be fixed here? The escape syntax pattern matching logic or the list of patterns in that array?

tracker-extract-3 excessive CPU capacity consumption issue, with gnome-software open

note.body:
Thanks for the detailed logs.

In Tracker 3.7, there is no systemd user service for tracker-extract. Instead, the tracker-miner-fs-3 process is responsible for managing this on a private bus (this change was needed for tighter sandboxing rules that you can read about [here](https://blogs.gnome.org/carlosg/2023/10/10/on-cve-2023-43641/)).

In the logs I see two messages repeated over and over again:

```
Eki 12 16:13:52 fedora tracker-miner-f[3230]: Extractor subprocess died unexpectedly: Alt işlem 1 kodu ile sonlandı
Eki 12 16:13:53 fedora tracker-miner-fs-3[115377]: (tracker-extract-3:115377): Tracker-CRITICAL **: 16:13:53.988: Could not connect to filesystem miner endpoint: Error opening database: Could not open sqlite3 database:'/home/macellan/.cache/tracker3/files/meta.db': unable to open database file
```

The first of these comes from here, which is the tracker-miner-fs-3 process: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/blob/main/src/miners/fs/tracker-extract-watchdog.c#L329

The second is from  here in the tracker-extract-3 process: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/blob/main/src/tracker-extract/tracker-main.c#L403

My guess is that there are two problems:

  1. The filesystem indexer tracker-miner-fs-3 is somehow unable to create a database
  2. The filesystem indexer keeps restarting tracker-extract-3

This is just a guess at this point , I took 15 minutes out of my work day to look into this for you but I don't have more time to dig in right now.

As for a workaround, there is no systemd user service for tracker-extract-3 any more, did you try masking the tracker-miner-fs-3 service? This may or may not be a complete workaround as D-Bus activation from apps trying to run searches, could still activate the tracker-miner-fs-3 process.

note.body:
The issue is journalctl uses a "pager" by default, which is useful for interactively viewing the journal, but not useful for copy/pasting the whole thing.

If you add `--no-pager` to the journalctl commandline, you'll see the full output in the terminal. You can redirect this to a file (add `> my-log.txt` to the commandline, in Bash) and then upload the file here so we see the full output.

You can see more documentation for journalctl if you run `man journalctl` in the terminal.

note.body:
Strange that it's getting an error opening the database. Also the path `/home/macellan/.ca` is weird but I will guess it's been truncated by journalctl, and is actually `.cache/tracker3/files/...` as we'd expect.

This could be DB corruption. To check, could you try:

     cp -a $HOME/.cache/tracker3/files $HOME/.cache/tracker3/backup
     tracker3 reset --filesystem --database

This will cause filesystem indexing to start again from scratch, and if the problem goes away, we can be sure that it was probably DB corruption.

target_title: Too-permissive Landlock rules in tracker-extract

note.body:
Thanks for this issue report. I am unclear that these are completely pointless, they were added as precisely $HOME can be part of the [indexed_folders array](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/blob/2feb828ab370d8d23cb9197c507efec3368a40b2/src/libtracker-miners-common/tracker-landlock.c#L255) (and with the default settings, it will), so IIUC these rules would still trim down the READ_FILE bit.

It's however possible that the user changed the indexer configuration so that direct $HOME contents are not indexed, in that case those rules would indeed open a small gap to listing directory contents, but it's reasonably straightforward to check that $HOME is (not) in `indexed_folders`.

note.body:
Thanks for the report. Never seen that log before and it doesn't have any useful info.

To get some usable logs, try `systemctl --user stop localsearch.service`. Then run localsearch manually with some debug flags enabled in the environment. The binary is usually `/usr/libexec/localsearch` I think.

Logs you could enable: `TINYSPARQL_DEBUG=sparql LOCALSEARCH_DEBUG=miner-fs-events,config,decorator`. (Full list at https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/tinysparql/-/blob/main/src/libtracker-common/tracker-debug.c?ref_type=heads and https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/localsearch/-/blob/main/src/libtracker-miners-common/tracker-debug.c )

I'm sort of guessing at what happens, but there must be a bug at work here -- well two bugs, as it should log useful errors, and should log them only once and not infinitely.
